content:
Passengers onboard the LIRR's 7:37AM from Huntington arrive at Penn Station at 10:07; exactly 90 minutes late after a power failure in East River tunnels this morning.  

Just some of the tens of thousands of rush hour commuters who suffered through long delays.  I'll continue to follow the situation at Penn Station, with updates throughout the day and later this evening on Eyewitness News.  #LIRR
name: NJ Burkett

content: Amtrak rail workers have completed their repairs on a damaged third rail outside the East River tunnels. The LIRR says a routine evening rush hour is expected.  (I suppose we'll see!)  #LIRR
name: NJ Burkett
title: Timeline Photos

content:
Viktor Yashchyshyk left Ukraine eleven years ago, hoping to find a better life in America.  And he did.  Until last week.  

He was walking his dog Hugo near his home in Old Bridge, NJ when he was brutally beaten.  One eyewitness says the attacker grabbed Hugo by the leash, twirling him like a lasso, until the collar slipped off and the dog escaped.  

Viktor was found unconscious on the sidewalk, with several missing teeth.  In 48 hours, he would be dead from a traumatic brain injury.  

Hugo ran home and was found on Viktor's doorstep.  The family says he's listless and heartbroken.  

Police say the attack was random, senseless and entirely unprovoked.  

It happened at 9PM, exactly one week ago tonight.  One suspect, a 20 year-old from Sayreville, is in custody and the investigation is not over.  Eyewitness News, 11PM tonight.
name: NJ Burkett
title: Photos from NJ Burkett's post

content:
Random, brutal and unprovoked.   

I'm truly at a loss after meeting the friends and family of Viktor Yashchyshyk.  He left Ukraine eleven years ago, hoping to find a better life in America, only to be murdered in his own neighborhood.  

Wednesday's 11PM report
name: NJ Burkett
title: Wake held for immigrant beaten and killed walking dog in NJ

content:
My concentration face, right before the liveshot.  (One of these days, they'll catch me on TV doing this!)  

So, what's yours?
name: NJ Burkett
title: Timeline Photos

content:
Chaos on the Grand Concourse tonight after a young mother shoves her little boy down a flight of stairs in his stroller.  

John Smith, an eyewitness, says the woman appeared distraught, cursing and shouting, "I can't do this!" before she pushed the stroller and the child down the steps of the 149th Street station in The Bronx. 

Neither mother nor child has been identified and charges have not yet been announced.  The child is two years-old and was rushed to the hospital in stable condition.  The precise nature of his injuries could not immediately be confirmed.  

Smith told me the mother remained at the scene, leaning against a wall with a blank expression on her face, until police arrived.  

Eyewitness News, after the NBA tonight.
name: NJ Burkett
title: Photos from NJ Burkett's post

content:
Okay, friends, question for you:  Have you ever shared a taxi with a stranger?  If you haven't, would you?  (As for me, I actually shared a cab last Thursday night after work.)

Why do I ask?  Ridesharing comes to New York's medallion cabs this week.  So, how does it work?  And who's using it??  

See you tonight on Eyewitness News at 5!
name: NJ Burkett
title: Timeline Photos

content: No matter where I find myself, it's my favorite time of day.
name: NJ Burkett
title: Timeline Photos

content:
Would you share a taxi with a stranger?  

Check out tonight's report on the new ridesharing program for medallion cabs in New York City.  

And two more reasons to watch:  My cringeworthy pun at the end of the piece and the master class in shooting and editing by WABC-TV photographer Rob Cantwell.
name: NJ Burkett
title: Via, Curb push New Yorkers to share taxis at a discount

content:
EXCLUSIVE:  Tears stream down the cheek where the bullet grazed her face.  

18 year-old Tyshamik Manuel was on Broadway in Bushwick, walking with her cousins, when gunfire sent them running for their lives.  She remembers at least four shots before her cousin, Kieth Kyser, fell to the pavement with two shots to the chest.  

One of the bullets whizzed past her head, and left a mark that was still visible this afternoon.  She can't believe she's alive and can't believe her cousin is dead.  

Tyshamik tells me she has no idea why Kieth was targeted.  But witnesses say this was not a random crime.  

Eyewitness News tonight at 6.
name: NJ Burkett
title: Photos from NJ Burkett's post

content:
Did you know that, by some estimates, eighty percent of the cigarettes sold in New York City are sold illegally?  

Tonight, authorities are cracking down with sweeping indictments and one of the largest seizures of illegal cigarettes and cigars ever made in the metropolitan area.  

Our exclusive report on Eyewitness News at 5.
name: NJ Burkett
title: Photos from NJ Burkett's post

content:
It's one of the best things about my job--meeting people who watch Eyewitness News.  

And a lot of them have been watching for a long time.  And they're the children of parents who watched the great Bill Beutel and Roger Grimsby.  

Like Bronx bodega owner, Mohammed Nagi, whose parents emigrated here from Yemen.  He started watching WABC-TV in 1982.  

But Xzaiver and Kazier Martin are some of our youngest viewers.  I met them with their mom, Khaliyah Martin, as I was headed to the subway at 125th Street.  

And, by the way, I say an emphatic NO to those trying to rename the southern edge of Harlem "SoHa."  (That's offensive.  If you live in Harlem, say you live in Harlem and be proud of it.)
name: NJ Burkett
title: Photos from NJ Burkett's post

content:
By some estimates, eighty percent of the cigarettes sold in New York City are sold illegally.

name: NJ Burkett
title: Exclusive: Illegal cigarettes are big business in NYC

content:
BREAKING:  Gunman opens fire on Republican congressmen on a softball field just outside D.C. in Alexandria, Virginia.  

Five reported hit.  The extent of their injuries is not clear; conditions cannot be confirmed.  Gunman is reported to have been captured or killed after a minutes-long shootout with officers.  

Stay tuned to Channel 7 and ABC7NY for details as the situation continues to unfold.
name: NJ Burkett

content:
I'm taking a long weekend in The Lone Star State!  

It was great seeing the Modern Art Museum of Ft Worth.  A really sensational collection, from Andy Warhol to Jenny Holzer and John Chamberlain.  

I'm off to see my dad's boyhood home in McKinney on Saturday morning, then to Dallas for a tour of Dealey Plaza and other historic sites in the afternoon.
name: NJ Burkett
title: Photos from NJ Burkett's post

content:
Happy Father's Day, my friends!  

Special thanks to our social media producer, Jamie Nguyen who put together this terrific tribute to the fathers and sons of Eyewitness News.
name: NJ Burkett
title: Eyewitness News Team celebrates Father's Day

content:
Here's a beautiful tribute to her dad from my friend, Lucy.  Not all of us are fortunate, as am I, to have our dads with us today.  

But we are all fortunate for the time we do have.
name: NJ Burkett
title: Lucy Yang

content:
On Father's Day weekend, I made a trip to McKinney, Texas, where my dad was raised.  I hadn't been there since I was a child, so things looked pretty different.  

The road to McKinney from Dallas is a huge interstate and the cattle pastures that stretched for miles are long gone.  

But dad's home, on West Virginia Street, was still there (it's not white anymore) and so was the home of my great-grandmother, Mary Francis Thompson, just a few blocks up the street.  At some point, it was turned into a bed and breakfast.

And the former law office of my great-great grandfather, who built the building after he returned from the war, is still there.  It's a bistro now. 

The city is thriving.  And it was great to see!
name: NJ Burkett
title: Photos from NJ Burkett's post

This was one of the most bizarre stories I've covered in a long time.  

A runaway bus rolls backwards for three city blocks.  You have to see this cellphone video to believe it.  And no, nobody was killed.
name: NJ Burkett
title: Crazy video: Runaway bus rolls backwards, slams into church

content:
When Gabe Pressman spoke, you listened.  Not just because he was Gabe Pressman, but because he had something to say.  And because you wanted to know what Gabe thought about just about everything.  

Insightful, thoughtful, wise.  And kind.  Those are the words I'd use to describe a man I admired deeply and respected thoroughly.  Gabe passed away overnight at the age of 93.  

You may not know this, but Gabe was the original television news reporter.  The first TV newsman to go into the street with portable equipment to cover stories in the field.

Gabe and I became friends several years ago, after I was inducted into the Inner Circle of City Hall Journalists, where Gabe began performing in the annual show some forty years earlier.  He cared passionately about journalism and was a fierce defender the First Amendment.  

And even into his nineties, he was still belting out songs onstage at the Inner Circle Show.  As sharp and as engaged as ever.  

"Over the course of his long and distinguished career," Gov Andrew Cuomo said today, "Gabe was the North Star for several generations of New York reporters, fighting doggedly to hold public officials accountable and to protect the rights of the press."  The Governor was absolutely right, and I was one of those reporters.  

The word icon is overused these days.  But Gabe was an icon.  He loved journalism and he loved New York City.
name: NJ Burkett
title: Photos from NJ Burkett's post

content:
Human error was the cause of Tuesday's A-Train derailment in Harlem.  

We broke the story on Eyewitness News at 11 and, minutes after our report, the MTA issued a statement confirming it: 

"The preliminary investigation of Tuesday morning's  train derailment indicates the cause was an improperly secured piece of replacement rail that was stored on the tracks; the cause appears to be human error, not a track defect. 

"Storing equipment in between tracks is a common practice employed by railroads across the country to accelerate rail repairs. The key to this being an effective and safe practice is making sure that the extra equipment is properly bolted down, which does not appear to have happened in this case. 

"NYCT is inspecting every inch of rail to ensure that each and every replacement part is properly stored and secured. Nothing is more important than the safety of our customers. 

"The investigation into this incident continues."
name: NJ Burkett
title: Sources: 'A' train derailment caused by unsecured rail
